raw_text:
Murray to make Cup history
 
 Andrew Murray will become Britain's youngest-ever Davis Cup player after it was confirmed he will play in the doubles against Israel on Saturday.
 
 The 17-year-old will play alongside fellow debutant David Sherwood against Israel's Jonathan Erlich and Andy Ram. Murray will eclipse the record set by Roger Becker back in 1952. Greg Rusedski takes Tim Henman's place as first choice in the singles, while Alex Bogdanovic will play in the second singles clash. Rusedski will take on former world number 30 Harel Levy and Bogdanovic - who has previously played in two singles rubbers against Australia - will face Noam Okun.
 
 Murray is the brightest young hope in British tennis, after winning the US Open junior title last year and the BBC Young Sports Personality of the Year. British number one Tim Henman, who announced his Davis Cup retirement earlier this year, believes Britain can win the tie in Tel Aviv. "It's going to be as really tough match. Israel have some really good players - and their doubles pair of Andy Ram and Jonathan Erlich are among the top eight in the world - but I fancy our chances," he said. But Henman urged Bogdanovic, who has had run-ins with British tennis officials in the past, to seize his chance. "Alex is a quality player - he's young but he's got to keep pushing forward. "He's got to be stronger, he's got a lot of ability but he's got to be more disciplined mentally and physically and if he does that he's got a good chance."

He will play alongside David Sherwood against Jonathan Erlich and Andy Ram, eclipsing Roger Becker's record from 1952.
Greg Rusedski replaces Tim Henman as first choice in singles, while Alex Bogdanovic plays in the second singles match against Harel Levy and Noam Okun.

qwen2.5:0.5b:
British Tennis: Andrew Murray becomes Davis Cup youngest player after qualifying for doubles against Israel

In the Davis Cup men's singles tennis event, British player Andrew Murray will play in his second singles clash as an international player.
He has qualified for the tournament with his second-round match against David Sherwood and Jonathan Erlich, while Andy Ram is playing against Alex Bogdanovic.
Britain faces a tough challenge from Israel, which boasts talented players like Andy Ram and Jonathan Erlich.
However, British number one Tim Henman predicts that a strong player like Murray can still make it to Tel Aviv.

Murray, who has already achieved the record for Britain's youngest-ever Davis Cup player, is believed to be playing in his first singles match of the tournament after winning the US Open junior title last year and earning the BBC Young Sports Personality of the Year award.
He will face Noam Okun in his second singles clash against Bogdanovic.

Henman urges Murray to stay focused on his growing reputation as a young player before taking on more experienced opponents, while he also encourages Bogdanovic to continue pushing himself forward despite some past disagreements with British officials.

Tim Henman, who announced his Davis Cup retirement earlier this year, believes Britain has a strong chance of winning.
Bogdanovic is urged to prove himself mentally and physically stronger despite having run-ins with British tennis officials in the past.

British number one Tim Henman believes Britain can win the tie despite strong Israeli players including Andy Ram and Jonathan Erlich.
Henman urges Bogdanovic to improve mentally and physically for his chances.

Greg Rusedski [will play Tim Henman's place as first choice in singles], while Alex Bogdanovic will play in the second doubles match against Harel Levy and [Noam Okun].

"[Tim] has shown fantastic skill and determination over the years.
It's a testament to what he can achieve when he gives it his all."
